isis.stitle: 7.3 Liter Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1991) - ENGINE DIAGNOSTIC TEST PROCEDURES FOR 7.3 LITER DIESEL ENGINES - EXTERNAL LEAKAGE - AIR INDUCTION TEST

item.para: Air pressure regulator with 0-30 psi gauge.
Soap (children's bubble blowing soap is best).
1.040 in. plug with air hose connector. (Make locally).
2 hose clamps (1.5 in. and 4.5 in. dia.).

figure.caption: Figure 5.3 Required Tools for Air Induction Test

step1.para: Block off the air cleaner inlet snorkel, using the clean plastic trash bag, duct tape and 4.5 in. hose clamp as shown in Figure 5.4.

Remove the CDR intake manifold hose from the CDR mounting spud. Install the 1.040 in. plug with air hose connector. Attach an air hose with a pressure regulator and 0-30 psi gauge. Refer to Figure 5.4.

Regulate air pressure being introduced into the CDR hose to 6-9 psi. A constant supply of air is required to compensate for internal leakage past the open intake valves and the air inlet snorkel to filter housing mating surface.

note.para: Leakage from the air inlet snorkel can be reduced by applying a bead of silicone sealant around the snorkel to housing mating surface. This is not mandatory, but will improve the sensitivity of the test.

step1.para: Using a spray bottle with "bubble blowing" soap, coat the following areas and check for leaks. Leaks will cause air bubbles to form.

step2.para: Restriction indicator spud and air cleaner housing wing nut and sealing washer. Refer to Figure 5.5. No leakage is permissible.

figure.caption: Figure 5.5 Leakage Check at Air Cleaner Housing

step2.para: Air cleaner sealing gasket at the intake manifold inlet. Refer to Figure 5.6. No leakage is permissible.

figure.caption: Figure 5.6 Leakage Check at Intake Manifold Sealing Gasket

step2.para: All intake manifold and cylinder head mating surfaces. Refer to Figure 5.7. No leakage is permissible.

figure.caption: Figure 5.7 Leakage Check at Intake Manifold and Cylinder Head Mating Surfaces

step2.para: CDR hose inlet into the intake manifold. Refer to Figure 5.8. No leakage is permissible.

figure.caption: Figure 5.8 Leakage Check at CDR Hose Inlet to Intake Manifold [ 1988 MODEL YEAR SHOWN ]

step1.para: If the system holds pressure and NO leaks are detected, no further action is required beyond inspecting the air cleaner element for holes, damaged seals and sooting. Replace as required.

If leakage is detected, remove the air cleaner housing and the intake manifold inlet screen. Using your finger, sample the oil film in the inlet manifold for grit. If grit is felt, dirt has entered the engine.

item.para: Oil in the intake manifold is normal and expected, due to carry-over of oil vapors by the CDR valve.

Any leaks found in air induction system could have allowed dirt to enter engine. Dirt entering engine can cause high oil consumption because of badly worn or broken piston rings, excessive blue smoke. If any leaks are found in the air intake system, you can check the internal condition of the engine by running a crankcase pressure check.

step1.para: Service the engine as required after determining the extent of the damage.
Also correct any area which was identified as a point of leakage (i.e. sealing gaskets, air cleaner housing distortion, etc.).

note.para: A low air cleaner restiction reading or a lack of movement by the air cleaner restriction indicator could be caused by a plugged/ restricted fitting. The air cleaner restriction indicator spud is not a serviceable part, thus a restriction requires that it be reworked by drilling a 1/32" size hole through the center. Reworking will eliminate false air cleaner restiction readings. DO NOT ALLOW DRILLING DEBRIS TO ENTER THE INTAKE MANIFOLD. Refer to Figure 5.9.

figure.caption: Figure 5.9 Air Cleaner Restiction Indicator Spud
